questions.text: A 74-year-old Hispanic man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of dizziness upon standing and a brief loss of consciousness one hour ago. The patient suddenly collapsed on his way to the bathroom after waking up in the morning. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gout. The patient's mother died of a grand mal seizure at the age of 53 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. Current medications include ranitidine, dutasteride, tamsulosin, and allopurinol. He is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. He appears pale. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A plopping sound is heard on auscultation, immediately followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cardiac myxomas are most commonly located in the left atrium. They may be pedunculated, in which case they often present with position-dependent symptoms of obstructed blood flow through the atrioventricular valves, or they may embolize systemically. Additionally, patients may present with constitutional findings (e.g., weight loss, fever, or anemia). The typical auscultatory finding (also present in this patient) is an early diastolic “plop”, caused by a movement of the mobile tumor mass, followed by a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex that results from the obstructed blood flow through the mitral valve, and mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis. Echocardiography is the diagnostic test of choice to visualize the tumor and to assess its location, size, attachment, and mobility. The only definitive treatment of cardiac myxoma is surgical resection.
Image Description:

Echocardiography (transthoracic; apical 4-chamber view)

A rounded mass (green overlay) arises from the wall of the left atrium (LA).

LV: left ventricle; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle

B) INCORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic, but can also be alcohol-induced. It usually manifests with signs of heart failure. While this patient consumes critical levels of alcohol and displays symptoms that may suggest impaired pump function of the heart (syncope, hypotension), dilated cardiomyopathy does not manifest with a position-dependent diastolic heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease and may also manifest with dizziness and syncope. It should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in an older patient with a heart murmur, such as this one. The auscultatory finding of aortic valve stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur heard best over the 2nd right intercostal space. However, this patient has a rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex, which is not consistent with aortic valve stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis should be suspected in any patient presenting with fever and a new heart murmur. While this patient has a murmur on auscultation, he is afebrile, making an infectious origin of his symptoms less likely. The occurrence of position-dependent symptoms and a peculiar plopping sound suggest another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Various drugs can cause (orthostatic) hypotension and may lead to syncope, including alpha-1 blockers. This patient is taking an alpha-1 blocker and presents with orthostatic hypotension. However, among the alpha-1 blockers, tamsulosin is the agent with the lowest potential of inducing hypotension because of its increased selectivity for alpha-1 receptors of the bladder neck and the prostatic urethra. The peculiar heart murmur of a diastolic “plop” followed by a rumble suggests a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with syncope, orthostatic hypotension (a drop of ≥ 20 mm Hg in systolic pressure from supine to standing), and a diastolic murmur over the apex, all of which suggest an obstruction of the blood flow into the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a 2-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stokes-Adams attacks are characterized by a sudden loss of consciousness, usually without warning and lasting for a few seconds. However, these episodes of fainting are caused by an abnormal heart rhythm (especially complete atrioventricular block) and not due to a mechanical obstruction of blood flow.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease and may manifest with dizziness and syncope. It should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in an older patient with a heart murmur, such as this one. The auscultatory finding in aortic valve stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the 2nd right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.

C) CORRECT:

Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor, commonly located in the left atrium. They may be pedunculated, in which case they often present with position-dependent symptoms of obstructed blood flow through the atrioventricular valves, or they may embolize. Additionally, patients may present with constitutional findings (e.g., weight loss, fever, or anemia). The typical auscultatory finding (also present in this patient) is an early diastolic “plop,” caused by a movement of the mobile tumor mass, followed by a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex that results from the obstructed blood flow through the mitral valve, and mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Various drugs can cause (orthostatic) hypotension and may lead to syncope, including alpha-1 blockers. This patient is taking an alpha-1 blocker and presents with orthostatic hypotension. However, among the alpha-1 blockers, tamsulosin is the agent with the lowest potential of inducing hypotension because of its increased selectivity for alpha-1 receptors of the bladder neck and the prostatic urethra. The peculiar heart murmur of a diastolic “plop” followed by a rumble suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic but can also be alcohol-induced. It usually manifests with signs of heart failure. While this patient consumes critical levels of alcohol, and has symptoms that may suggest impaired pump function of the heart (syncope, hypotension), dilated cardiomyopathy does not manifest with a position-dependent diastolic heart murmur.
questions.hint: This patient presents with syncope, orthostatic hypotension (drop of ≥ 20 mm Hg in systolic pressure from supine to standing), and a diastolic murmur over the apex, all of which raise suspicion for an obstruction of blood flow into the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset slurred speech and right-sided weakness. Physical examination shows expressive aphasia, right facial droop, and decreased muscle strength in the right arm and leg. A CT angiogram of the head shows a thrombus in the left middle cerebral artery, and endovascular thrombectomy is performed. Microscopic examination of the retrieved thrombus shows mucoid, gelatinous material that is hypocellular. This thrombus most likely originated from which of the following anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The aortic valve is a common location for the formation of an infectious vegetation in the course of infective endocarditis. This patient does not have manifestations of infective endocarditis (e.g., fevers, Osler nodes, Roth spots). The aortic valve is not a common location for a myxoma, which is the origin of this patient's embolic stroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic material formed in the right atrium can only be the source of an embolic event if there is a pre-existing right-to-left shunt (e.g., paradoxical embolism due to a persistent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect). This patient does not have symptoms of cardiac shunting. Moreover, the right atrium is not a common location for a myxoma, which is the origin of this patient's embolic stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

The aortic arch is a possible location for the formation of atherosclerosis, which can lead to the formation of atheroemboli and ischemic strokes. It is not a common location for a myxoma, which is the origin of this patient's embolic stroke.

D) CORRECT:

Cardiac myxomas are the most common cardiac tumor in adults, and over 75% of all myxomas originate in the left atrium. They are benign tumors of mesenchymal origin and classically cause syncopal episodes (due to mitral valve outflow obstruction) and symptoms from thromboembolic events, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a sample of a mass removed from the wall of the left atrium (H&E stain; 20x and 40x)

Scarce cells are dispersed in abundant hyaline stroma mainly comprised of mucopolysaccharides (homogeneous, pale-pink, amorphous substance).
Erythrocytes are seen in some areas of the tissue, indicating marked hemorrhage.
At 40x magnification, multiple spindle cells with oval nuclei are visible.

E) INCORRECT:

The carotid artery is commonly involved in atherosclerosis, which can lead to atheroemboli and ischemic strokes. It is not a common location for a myxoma, which is the origin of this patient's embolic stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

In the case of an existing right-to-left shunt (paradoxical embolism), thrombotic material that forms in the femoral veins (e.g., due to deep vein thrombosis) can cause a cerebrovascular thromboembolic event. However, this patient does not have any manifestations of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., unilateral leg erythema and edema). The femoral veins are not a common location for a myxoma, which is the origin of this patient's embolic stroke.
questions.hint: A thrombus containing mucus and gelatinous material suggests that this patient's thromboembolus occurred due to an underlying myxoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for fatigue and swelling in her legs. She has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss in the past 8 months despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness, and has not seen a physician in over 15 years. Physical examination shows a brown-black, asymmetrical macule on her left shoulder. Cardiac examination shows jugular venous distention and an S3 gallop best heard over the apex. Pitting edema is present in the bilateral lower extremities up to the mid-shin. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a nonmobile mass protruding from the interatrial septum into the right atrium that partially occludes the tricuspid valve. A biopsy of the mass is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells
Clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity
Sheets of large, atypical B cells with prominent nucleoli
Mixture of cells from different germinal layers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells are observed in biopsy samples of rhabdomyoma. These are the most common primary cardiac tumors in children but are significantly less common in adults. The majority of intracardiac rhabdomyomas arise in association with tuberous sclerosis, of which this patient has no clinical manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity suggest cardiac myxomas, the most common primary cardiac tumors. Histologic findings include mesenchymal cells within a mucoid, gelatinous stroma. Cardiac myxomas can cause systemic symptoms such as fatigue and weight loss (due to production of interleukin 6), as seen here. However, the vast majority of these tumors occur as a mobile, pedunculated mass in the left atrium, rather than the right. Typically, cardiac myxomas manifest with symptoms of obstruction of blood flow through the heart (e.g., syncope, dyspnea, palpitations), a mid-diastolic murmur (similar to mitral stenosis), and/or a tumor plop on auscultation. Furthermore, primary cardiac neoplasms (e.g., cardiac myxoma) are not the most likely cause of cardiac tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Sheets of large, atypical B cells with prominent nucleoli are consistent with non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Lymphomatous lesions can arise in cardiac tissue, but these are quite rare, accounting for ∼ 1% of cardiac tumors. This patient's weight loss is suspicious for cancer; however, a diagnosis other than non-Hodgkin lymphoma is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A mixture of cells from different germinal layers is the characteristic finding of a teratoma. Cardiac involvement in teratoma cases is exceptionally rare, and, when encountered, seen most often in children. Moreover, teratomas tend to develop from the pericardium or the mediastinum rather than the endocardial lining. This patient's echocardiogram has identified an intracardiac neoplasm, which makes a teratoma very unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Nests of dysplastic melanocytes are seen in metastatic melanoma. Cardiac tumors can be classified as primary or secondary (metastatic). Metastatic tumors are approximately 20–30 times more common than primary cardiac tumors and more commonly occur on the right side of the heart. This patient's history of weight loss in combination with the asymmetrical mole raises suspicion of an occult melanoma that has metastasized to the heart. Melanoma is the most frequently implicated cancer, followed by lung and breast cancer.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of right-sided heart failure (JVD, S3 heart sound, pitting edema) due to a right atrial mass that is most likely causing obstruction of the tricuspid valve. Cardiac tumors are most commonly seen in the setting of metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of mild fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a mid-diastolic plopping sound heard best at the apex and bilateral rales at the base of the lungs. Echocardiography shows a pedunculated, heterogeneous mass in the left atrium. A biopsy of the mass shows clusters of mesenchymal cells surrounded by gelatinous material. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's fever is most likely caused by IL-6, a cytokine that stimulates the production of acute phase reactants and is secreted by cardiac myxomas. This patient's cardiopulmonary symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea) and examination findings (mid-diastolic murmur, bilateral rales) are due to left atrium obstruction and resultant pulmonary edema. The treatment for cardiac myxoma is surgical resection.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased S100 protein serum concentration is found in malignant melanoma. While melanomas are likely to metastasize to the heart, the pedunculated appearance seen in this patient's echocardiography and biopsy findings indicates cardiac myxoma, a primary cardiac tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Axillary lymphadenopathy is seen in several conditions, including malignancy. Malignancy and subsequent cardiac metastases, which are the most common cardiac tumors, may explain this patient's echocardiography findings and symptoms of left atrial obstruction. However, the pedunculated appearance of the tumor on echocardiography and biopsy findings indicate cardiac myxoma, which is typically benign and would not cause axillary lymphadenopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Malignant pleural effusion occurs with several cancers (e.g., lung cancer, breast cancer), some of which may metastasize to the heart. However, this patient's echocardiography and biopsy findings are consistent with cardiac myxoma, which is typically benign. Furthermore, malignant pulmonary effusion typically manifests unilaterally; this patient's bilateral pulmonary rales are more likely due to left atrium obstruction and resultant pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Ash-leaf skin lesions are a feature of tuberous sclerosis, which may also manifest with cardiac rhabdomyoma. While this patient's cardiopulmonary symptoms and echocardiography findings are consistent with a cardiac tumor, the biopsy findings are characteristic of cardiac myxoma rather than rhabdomyoma. Furthermore, tuberous sclerosis typically manifests during childhood, often with additional neurocognitive symptoms (e.g., intellectual disability, seizures) due to tumors in the central nervous system.
questions.hint: This patient's echocardiography and biopsy findings are characteristic of cardiac myxoma.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old otherwise healthy man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of syncope that occurred after he became acutely dyspneic and lightheaded while running. He sustained small lacerations but no head trauma. A review of systems reveals three episodes of transient left upper-extremity weakness that have occurred during the past month.
He is hospitalized with a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 138/80 mm Hg, and an early diastolic murmur. An echocardiogram shows a 3-cm mass, with irregular edges, that is attached to the interatrial septum and that intermittently prolapses through the mitral valve into the left ventricle.
What is the most appropriate definitive management approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biopsy is not indicated, as the appearance of the mass on echocardiography is characteristic for a myxoma, and management is not altered by the biopsy. Furthermore, biopsy may cause embolization of a portion of the myxoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiation of anticoagulation may reduce the risk for embolism but would not address the risks for syncope and sudden death associated with obstruction of the mitral valve orifice.

C) INCORRECT:

An intracardiac malignancy is rare, usually occurs as a result of advanced metastatic cancer (i.e., from the lung, breast, ovary, skin [melanoma], or lymph system), and differs in echocardiographic appearance from a myxoma. In a patient with no symptoms or signs of a primary tumor and an echocardiographic appearance typical for a myxoma, further oncologic evaluation to search for an alternate primary malignancy is unnecessary.

D) CORRECT:

Atrial myxomas, the most common cardiac tumors, vary in size and type of attachment (pedunculated vs. broad-based). They often are composed of gelatinous material with irregular borders. Multilobulated or pedunculated myxomas are often sufficiently mobile and may prolapse through the mitral valve during diastole. The risk for embolization is high.

Common clinical manifestations of atrial myxomas include stroke, transient ischemic attack, dyspnea, orthopnea, arrhythmia (if the tumor invades the conduction system), and sudden cardiac death (due to obstruction of blood flow through the mitral valve orifice). To manage the tumor definitively and reduce the risk for embolic and cardiovascular complications, refer a patient with an atrial myxoma for surgical excision.

Key learning point: The definitive treatment for a symptomatic left atrial myxoma is surgical excision.

E) INCORRECT:

Tumor ablation is generally not possible given the variable blood supply to the mass; in addition, it may result in significant complications, such as embolization.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is evaluated after a stroke. He reports a 3-month history of shortness of breath on exertion, two-pillow orthopnea, and bilateral lower-extremity edema. In addition, he has had fever, weight loss, and arthralgias for several months.
Physical examination reveals a prominent first heart sound and an early, low-pitched diastolic sound. An electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm.
MRI of the brain reveals multiple infarcts in the cerebellum. MRI of the abdomen reveals features consistent with renal and splenic infarcts.
Which one of the following cardiac diagnoses is most likely to account for this patient’s findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent foramen ovale can be a source of paradoxical embolism, but it is not associated with constitutional symptoms, symptoms of heart failure, or abnormal findings on cardiac examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve endocarditis may cause constitutional symptoms, but vegetations from this valve would embolize to the lungs, not to the systemic arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve calcification can be an embolic source, but neither aortic stenosis nor regurgitation yields the physical examination findings observed in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may cause heart failure but not constitutional symptoms or thromboembolic events.

E) CORRECT:

Cardiac tumors are potential sources of cerebral or peripheral embolic events. Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumors; the most frequent site is the left atrial cavity. Embolic events occur in one-third of cases. Dyspnea, orthopnea, and extremity edema may be due to mitral valve obstruction, regurgitation, or both. Constitutional symptoms (such as fever, weight loss, arthralgias, and Raynaud’s phenomenon) are observed in 50% of patients and may be related to overproduction of interleukin-6.

The loud first heart sound is related to delayed mitral valve closure, resulting from tumor prolapse through the orifice. An early diastolic sound, called a “tumor plop,” is related to contact between the tumor and the endocardial wall when its excursions are halted. Fever, cyanosis, digital clubbing, and petechiae may also be seen. Familial forms may be associated with nevi, lentigenes (freckles), and myxomas in breast, skin, thyroid, or neural tissue.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of cerebral and peripheral embolic events in a patient with constitutional symptoms, symptoms of heart failure, and a “tumor plop” on cardiac auscultation is atrial myxoma, the most common type of primary cardiac tumor.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man with hypertension reports 6 months of intermittent fevers, progressive shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, and chest pain.
On examination, his jugular venous pressure is normal, and he has faint bilateral crackles throughout both lung fields. He also has an early diastolic sound followed by a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. He has no conjunctival or skin lesions.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most consistent with this patient’s history and physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (marantic endocarditis) may manifest with signs and symptoms of systemic embolization. However, because the valvular lesions do not usually affect valvular function, they rarely cause significant murmurs.

B) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis of the mitral valve typically causes a holosystolic apical murmur (due to regurgitation) and not an isolated diastolic murmur. Additional physical examination findings may also be present, such as Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, splinter hemorrhages, or conjunctival petechiae.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacute aortic dissection would manifest as sharp chest pain with possible radiation to the back, not progressive shortness of breath or fevers.

D) CORRECT:

Cardiac myxomas are rare, benign, primary cardiac tumors that typically manifest with symptoms of cardiac obstruction (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea), systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, weight loss), or embolization. They are most often found in the left atrium and can cause obstruction of the mitral valve, which may be identified on physical examination as a diastolic tumor plop and a diastolic murmur that mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of fevers, progressive dyspnea, and an early diastolic sound followed by a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex is cardiac myxoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome, associated with flushing and diarrhea, affects only right-sided valves unless an intracardiac shunt or a bronchial carcinoid tumor is present. This is because the noxious substances secreted by the carcinoid tumor reach the right side of the heart via the systemic circulation but are then inactivated in the pulmonary circulation, which thus protects the left side of the heart. This patient’s murmur is located at the cardiac apex and, therefore, is likely to originate from the mitral valve.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with hypertension reports 6 months of intermittent fevers, progressive shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, and chest pain. On examination, his jugular venous pressure is normal, and he has faint bilateral crackles throughout both lung fields. He also has an early diastolic sound followed by a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. He has no conjunctival or skin lesions. Which one of the following diagnoses is most consistent with this patient’s history and physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (marantic endocarditis) may manifest with signs and symptoms of systemic embolization. However, because the valvular lesions do not usually affect valvular function, they rarely cause significant murmurs.

B) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis of the mitral valve typically causes a holosystolic apical murmur (due to regurgitation) and not an isolated diastolic murmur. Additional physical examination findings may also be present, such as Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, splinter hemorrhages, or conjunctival petechiae.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacute aortic dissection would manifest as sharp chest pain with possible radiation to the back, not progressive shortness of breath or fevers.

D) CORRECT:

Cardiac myxomas are rare, benign, primary cardiac tumors that typically manifest with symptoms of cardiac obstruction (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea), systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, weight loss), or embolization. They are most often found in the left atrium and can cause obstruction of the mitral valve, which may be identified on physical examination as a diastolic tumor plop and a diastolic murmur that mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of fevers, progressive dyspnea, and an early diastolic sound followed by a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex is cardiac myxoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome, associated with flushing and diarrhea, affects only right-sided valves unless an intracardiac shunt or a bronchial carcinoid tumor is present. This is because the noxious substances secreted by the carcinoid tumor reach the right side of the heart via the systemic circulation but are then inactivated in the pulmonary circulation, which thus protects the left side of the heart. This patient’s murmur is located at the cardiac apex and, therefore, is likely to originate from the mitral valve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a brief syncopal episode while climbing stairs. She reports several weeks of intermittent lightheadedness, exertional dyspnea, and episodes of left-hand tingling that resolve spontaneously. She also notes fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and occasional low-grade fevers. She has no history of intravenous drug use, recent dental procedures, or prosthetic valves. Vital signs are BP, 104/64 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 20; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft, low-frequency extra sound just after S2 followed by a variable mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, both of which change in intensity with body position. There is mild livedo reticularis on her left hand. ECG shows sinus rhythm without ischemic changes, and chest x-ray reveals mild cardiomegaly. Laboratory studies show normal white blood cell count and normal troponin. Which of the following diagnoses best explains this constellation of findings?

choices.text: Mitral stenosis secondary to rheumatic heart disease
Left atrial thrombus secondary to paroxysmal atrial fibrillation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has low-grade fever and embolic phenomena, she lacks risk factors such as intravenous drug use, prosthetic valves, or recent invasive procedures. The positional variation in her symptoms and diastolic sound cannot be explained by vegetations, which are fixed to valve leaflets and move only with valve motion, not with changes in body position. Her normal white blood cell count and lack of systemic infection further argue against endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can produce exertional syncope but typically causes a systolic murmur that increases with Valsalva, not a positional diastolic sound. Embolic or constitutional features are not seen.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — Cardiac myxoma is a benign neoplasm, usually arising in the left atrium, that presents with a triad of obstructive, embolic, and constitutional symptoms. Obstructive symptoms (dyspnea, syncope) vary with position due to intermittent mitral valve obstruction. Embolic phenomena cause transient limb or neurologic deficits, and constitutional symptoms result from cytokine release. The early diastolic “tumor plop” that changes with posture is characteristic.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis also presents with exertional dyspnea and a diastolic murmur, but it is fixed in timing and associated with a loud S1 and opening snap. Fever, embolic symptoms, and variability with position are inconsistent with rheumatic mitral disease.

E) INCORRECT:

A left atrial thrombus may produce embolic phenomena similar to those seen here. They typically occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation, mitral stenosis, or reduced left atrial contractility. Thrombi are usually mural and nonmobile, so they do not cause position-dependent obstruction or a variable diastolic sound. Additionally, thrombi do not cause constitutional symptoms seen here, e.g., fatigue, low-grade fever, and weight loss.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents after a syncopal episode. She reports a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, a 15-pound weight loss, and intermittent fevers. Physical examination shows a middiastolic rumbling murmur that varies in intensity with position changes. Echocardiography results are shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography would not provide additional diagnostic information beyond what echocardiography has already shown and would delay necessary urgent surgical treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is contraindicated in cardiac myxoma because it does not prevent tumor embolization and may increase bleeding risk during necessary surgical intervention.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a confirmed diagnosis of cardiac myxoma with a large, mobile mass. Urgent surgical resection is required due to the high risk of systemic embolization, cerebral infarction, and sudden death.

D) INCORRECT:

While transesophageal echocardiography can provide additional detail about tumor attachment and morphology, the diagnosis is already established. The priority is urgent surgical intervention based on the size and mobility of the tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not indicated in cardiac myxoma evaluation because it provides no additional diagnostic information and may carry risk of tumor embolization during the procedure.
